titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Tehran Office Program Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Tehran Office Program Files FA1534

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-21 01:22:04 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Tehran Office Program Files
did.langmaterial: Materials in the collection are predominately in English. Many of the files also include original Persian documents with attached or accompanying English translations, documents with English and Persian versions, and documents entirely in Persian.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas. During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the program files of the Ford Foundation field office in Tehran, Iran. These files concern Foundation fellowships related to Iran and Iranian awardees as well as the two main focus areas of the Tehran Office's program activity: educational development and rural village development. Records are organized into three individual series based on these three different subjects. With materials spanning from 1952 to 1964, the collection documents the entire history of Ford Foundation support to Iran as conducted through the Tehran Field Office.

Correspondence, memos, drafts, notes, and reports within the collection were created by the Tehran Office program specialist/consultant staff (Paul Maris – Agricultural Development, Arthur Lewis – Education, Howard Bertsch – Rural Development) and representatives (Bertsch and Rey Hill). These records document communications between the Tehran staff and its supervising office, the Office of the Near East Representative in Beirut, Lebanon, other parts of the Ford Foundation, Iranian Government officials and staff, grantees like the Near East Foundation, collaborating organizations, and individual fellows. They also regard meetings between Foundation staff and Iranian Government officials, grant project proposals, approvals, progress, and close outs, coordination of travel awards for Iranian awardees, and assistance to Foundation fellows conducting research in Iran. In addition to the aforementioned material formats, there are some photographs and publications in the collection.

Materials in the collection originate from two different sets of records transferred to the Rockefeller Archive Center. Files in Series 1. Fellowships and Series 3. Rural village development programs originated from an accession of program strategy records, and files in Series 2. Education grants originated from an accession of grant records. The materials' original containers and content indicated that the records were initially all organized together and were thus processed as one Tehran Office Program Files collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011.

This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as parts of Accession 2019:046 Ford Foundation records, Program Strategy records and Accession 2019:049 Ford Foundation records, Grant records.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of three series.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Between 1952 and 1964, the Ford Foundation provided grant support to a number of different rural development and educational development projects in Iran. Programming in Iran was overseen by the Foundation's Office of the Near East Representative in Beirut, Lebanon. Work in the Tehran, Iran Field Office was conducted by a small number of program specialists/consultants and representative staff members. Over the years, program specialist/consultant staff included Paul Maris as an Agricultural Consultant, Arthur Lewis as a Program Specialist in Education, and Howard Bertsch as a Rural Development Consultant. Bertsch later served as a Consultant-Representative before Rey Hill succeeded him as Representative for Iran.

Ford issued grants directly to Iranian Government branches and organizations as well as to organizations providing assistance to Iran like the Near East Foundation. Rural development grants chiefly concerned agricultural credit cooperatives, village worker training programs, and projects that involved women in village development. Educational development grants chiefly concerned teacher training and curriculum development. The Tehran Office also coordinated Travel and Study Awards Program grants and other fellowships to individuals from Iran with the Beirut Office and assisted Ford fellows conducting research in Iran.
Ford Foundation programming in Iran was discontinued in 1964 as per the recommendations of Rey Hill.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection materials originated from two different sets of records transferred to the Rockefeller Archive Center: Accession 2019:046 Ford Foundation records, Program Strategy records and Accession 2019:049 Ford Foundation records, Grant records. The sequential box numbers on the original containers storing the materials suggested that the records were once kept together, and analysis of the containers' contents revealed that the documents all related to the Foundation's Tehran Office. It was then decided to process the documents from the two accessions into a single collection in accordance with the order of the original box numbers.

did.unittitle: Fellowships

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Series was processed into the collection from Accession 2019:046 Ford Foundation records, Program Strategy records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series mostly contains files regarding Ford Foundation fellowships granted to Iranian citizens as well as Ford fellows conducting research in Iran. Iranians granted Travel and Study Awards Program grants and special fellowships by the Foundation were primarily interested in agricultural and rural development. Some of the correspondence regarding the Travel and Study Awards Program grantees discusses the Foundation's emphasis on grantees returning to Iran in order to apply their acquired knowledge and skills to the improvement of their home country. Other documents in the series show how the Tehran Office assisted Ford fellows journeying to and staying in Iran for the purpose of their research.

The series also contains a small amount of material regarding the Ford Foundation's support of agricultural and rural development programs in Burma. This material is comprised of lists of Foundation supported projects in Burma, reports, publications, and correspondence. It is unclear why these documents were stored with the Tehran Office records when they seem to have been created by the Foundation's office in Rangoon, Burma. One connection may be the two offices' shared interest in rural development programming.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Series was processed into the collection from Accession 2019:049 Ford Foundation records, Grant records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains files regarding grants that the Ford Foundation provided for educational development in Iran. These grants appear to have primarily focused on teacher training and recruitment and curriculum development. Correspondence, drafts, reports, planning materials, financial statements, and photographs document the Foundation's grant support to the National Teachers' College for the purpose of teacher training and recruitment. The files concerning those grants also include materials that discuss the eventual abolishment of the National Teachers' College due to the belief that it did not serve the Iranian Government's needs. Other files in the series regard the Foundation's assistance to the Iranian Government's Ministry of Education on curriculum development for various academic subjects at different educational levels. Some of the correspondence in these files discuss reorganization within the Ministry and potential internal conflict.
The series also holds some files that regard Foundation grants for the production of educational materials like a Persian language dictionary.

did.unittitle: Science Teaching in the Middle East - Consultant on science education to the Ministry of Education, Project No. 61-371

Agricultural school at Shiraz University

did.physdesc: File contains a set of still images. Photographs have descriptive captions on their backs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photographs in the file regard the teacher-librarian training program at the National Teachers' College in Tehran, Iran. They document instructive sessions that were part of the course as well as the work of the apprenticeship teams that were assigned to different school libraries. Photograph captions provide information about the state of school libraries in Iran as well as the teacher-librarian training program. All of the photographs appear to have been created in 1960.

physdesc.extent: About 2.5 LGL and 1 Half-LGL size Hollinger boxes

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Series was processed into the collection from Accession 2019:046 Ford Foundation records, Program Strategy records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains files regarding the Ford Foundation's support of rural village development programs in Iran. The Foundation issued grants directly to the Iranian Government as well as to foreign organizations providing support to Iran like the Near East Foundation. Some files within the series document how over the course of the Tehran Office's history, the Ford Foundation sought to shift the focus of some of its activities in Iran in order to encourage the institutionalization of rural development programs by the Iranian Government and lessen Iran's dependency on foreign aid for programs like rural credit cooperatives. In addition to containing records concerning rural credit cooperatives, the series also holds materials that regard village worker training programs and projects that involved rural Iranian women in village development.
